awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Synthesis and Exploration of Graphitic Nanocapsules
awd_abstract_narration:
In this CAREER project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Alexander Star of the University of Pittsburgh will study how to synthesize graphitic nanocups and assemble them into nanocapsules that can capture and release chemicals and materials. Graphitic nanocups doped with nitrogen atoms will be synthesized, and the chemical derivatization of the nitrogen sites will be explored.  Via linker molecules with dual functionality, two cups will be assembled into a closed nanocapsule.

This work will enhance our fundamental understanding about how to generate nanoscale structures and manipulate them to do useful mechanical functions.  The results of these studies could have many important long term applications in which the capture and release of molecules are important, including drug delivery, sensing, and contaminant sequestration. The educational plan focuses on integrating experimental nanoscience into the four year curriculum of the chemistry major and then developing a capstone nanoscience course that students would take in their final year.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Carbon nanotubes are a unique material which has generated interest in both researchers and the general population alike due to their exciting electronic and physical properties. Further chemical modification of carbon nanotubes can be achieved through nitrogen doping which greatly alters the electronic properties in addition to the inherent structure of carbon nanotubes. The incorporation of nitrogen into the chemical composition of carbon nanotubes creates additional strain resulting in a new distinctive stacked cup structure. These nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube cups (NCNCs) have been the focus of this investigation where manipulation of the chemical and physical characteristics of the material has resulted in numerous practical applications. While this investigation has primarily contributed to technical and scientific advancements in the field of nanoscience, NCNCs have also been applied to several practical applications including fuel cells, cancer therapy, and chemical sensing.

            During this project large scale synthesis and appropriate characterization of NCNCs were investigated. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) was employed in order to synthesize NCNCs from xylene and acetonitrile which are chemicals that are easily accessible in a laboratory setting. Alterations were made to the CVD growth process in order to improve yield while controlling chemical and structural composition of NCNCs. Throughout the investigation it was determined that X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) in conjunction with Raman spectroscopy can effectively determine the chemical composition of NCNCs while transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and atomic force microscopy (AFM), and able to elucidate the structural properties. Additionally, techniques for separating NCNCs were improved from grinding with mortar and pestle to more sophisticated probe-tip ultrasonication. Decoration with multiple metal nanoparticles was performed with gold nanoparticle formation proving to be incredibly useful for various applications.

Current fuel cell technology is limited by the sluggish oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) which is currently catalyzed by costly and limited platinum metal. NCNCs were initially shown to have promising ORR potential in their as-synthesized state, however further modification allows for improvement of this activity. The chemical properties of NCNCs were altered by varying the transition metal used to synthesize NCNCs. This resulted in control over the ORR mechanism allowing for selection of the most efficient reduction mechanism. The physical structure of NCNCs also plays an important role in determining the electrocatalytic properties. To this end, NCNCs were unzipped through a common chemical procedure resulting in a unique hybrid graphene-nanotube structure where only the outer graphitic walls were unzipped. This hybrid nanostructure shows a drastic improvement in ORR activity due to the synergistic effects of increased surface area, and therefore active sites, with improved current density due to the conductive inner core providing an ideal morphology for future ORR electrocatalysts.

The unique stacked-cup structure of NCNCs makes them ideal candidates for drug delivery applications as their inherent cavity can be exploited to carry therapeutic agents. To this end, several different separation techniques were explored all of which being able to produce individual and short stacked segments of NCNCs. The individual segments require further modification in order to seal them, confining desired therapeutic agents inside the inner cavity. It was determined that gold nanoparticles (GNPs) preferentially grow on the open end of NCNCs, through a common synthesis process, affording sealed nanocontainers for pract...
por.por_txt_cntn:
Carbon nanotubes are a unique material which has generated interest in both researchers and the general population alike due to their exciting electronic and physical properties. Further chemical modification of carbon nanotubes can be achieved through nitrogen doping which greatly alters the electronic properties in addition to the inherent structure of carbon nanotubes. The incorporation of nitrogen into the chemical composition of carbon nanotubes creates additional strain resulting in a new distinctive stacked cup structure. These nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube cups (NCNCs) have been the focus of this investigation where manipulation of the chemical and physical characteristics of the material has resulted in numerous practical applications. While this investigation has primarily contributed to technical and scientific advancements in the field of nanoscience, NCNCs have also been applied to several practical applications including fuel cells, cancer therapy, and chemical sensing.

            During this project large scale synthesis and appropriate characterization of NCNCs were investigated. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) was employed in order to synthesize NCNCs from xylene and acetonitrile which are chemicals that are easily accessible in a laboratory setting. Alterations were made to the CVD growth process in order to improve yield while controlling chemical and structural composition of NCNCs. Throughout the investigation it was determined that X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) in conjunction with Raman spectroscopy can effectively determine the chemical composition of NCNCs while transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and atomic force microscopy (AFM), and able to elucidate the structural properties. Additionally, techniques for separating NCNCs were improved from grinding with mortar and pestle to more sophisticated probe-tip ultrasonication. Decoration with multiple metal nanoparticles was performed with gold nanoparticle formation proving to be incredibly useful for various applications.

Current fuel cell technology is limited by the sluggish oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) which is currently catalyzed by costly and limited platinum metal. NCNCs were initially shown to have promising ORR potential in their as-synthesized state, however further modification allows for improvement of this activity. The chemical properties of NCNCs were altered by varying the transition metal used to synthesize NCNCs. This resulted in control over the ORR mechanism allowing for selection of the most efficient reduction mechanism. The physical structure of NCNCs also plays an important role in determining the electrocatalytic properties. To this end, NCNCs were unzipped through a common chemical procedure resulting in a unique hybrid graphene-nanotube structure where only the outer graphitic walls were unzipped. This hybrid nanostructure shows a drastic improvement in ORR activity due to the synergistic effects of increased surface area, and therefore active sites, with improved current density due to the conductive inner core providing an ideal morphology for future ORR electrocatalysts.

The unique stacked-cup structure of NCNCs makes them ideal candidates for drug delivery applications as their inherent cavity can be exploited to carry therapeutic agents. To this end, several different separation techniques were explored all of which being able to produce individual and short stacked segments of NCNCs. The individual segments require further modification in order to seal them, confining desired therapeutic agents inside the inner cavity. It was determined that gold nanoparticles (GNPs) preferentially grow on the open end of NCNCs, through a common synthesis process, affording sealed nanocontainers for practical applications. The GNP corked NCNCs can be further isolated from any uncorked NCNCs resulting in a uniform sample for potential drug delivery applications.
